entry.title: New Zealand and sheep
entry.summary: Does New Zealand still deserve the sheep jokes?
entry.content:
When I say I grew up in New Zealand, a sheep joke often rears it’s head. I’ve always wondered how well that stereotype actually fit modern New Zealand. The claim we have 60,000,000 sheep comes up fairly frequently, but I had no idea if that was close to the contemporary population. Thankfully, Stats NZ provides the numbers, and below I’ve plotted the numbers I got from their website.1

So how many sheep are there?

So at one point there were 70,301,461 sheep in New Zealand. That was back in 1982 though. The number of sheep in 2013 was 30,904,714. Now I’m assuming this is sheep declared to the tax man (I’m hazy on where Stats NZ got such an exact number from), but I doubt it’s too much higher in reality.

To put the numbers in context, in 2012 there were 10.8 million sheep in the UK2 and 74.4 million in Australia3.

And the number per person?

So in 2013 there were 30,904,714 sheep and 4,504,600 people. So that’s 6.86 sheep to every person. Back in 1981 though, there 21.79 sheep to every person in New Zealand.

In 2012 in the UK, there were 0.2 sheep per person, and 3.3 per person in Australia.4 So compared to the British and Australians we’re the bigger sheep lovers. After the Kiwi’s, it’s the Welsh that tend to bare the brunt of the sheep jokes. In Wales there are 2.8 sheep to every person - so looks like the jokes are best directed at the Kiwi’s after all.

And how much is farm land?

New Zealand’s fertile lands gave it the nickname “Britain’s Breadbasket”5 and, historically at least, huge swathes of the country were farmland.

I’d love to know what happened in the 70’s and 80’s. I’m guessing the abrupt change may have had something to do with forestry, or it could be as mundane as a change in the way land was classified. The Stat NZ site doesn’t have detailed breakdowns from back then but the answer must be somewhere in the data.

A forestry report6 I found claims that in 2010 land use was supposedly broken down like below (I’ve replotted the reports pie graph as a bar chart, although I haven’t been fully converted to being a pie-chart zealot by Tufte yet7). While the UK was about 69% farmland and 9% forest in 2010.8

Despite NZ having the reputation of being greener, a greater of proportion of the UK is farmland. This doesn’t seem to make sense, and there may be some difference in how land use is measured, but it’s also due to the fact that around 30% of NZ is currently a national park9, while the proportion is only around 9% in the UK10.

While I was looking for the number of sheep in Australia I stumbled across a page on the Stats NZ site were they had already answered my first question.11 They’ve gone and explored a bunch of other myths about NZ as well, and the page is well worth a gander.

EDIT:: my cousin mentioned she’d like to see how the cow population has changed. Below I plotted the number of dairy cows, against beef cows, with deer and pigs thrown in. This data only starts in the 70’s, unlike the sheep data which starts in the 30’s.

And finally, to put the plot above in context, with sheep as well.

  1. Stats NZ site http://www.stats.govt.nz/tools_and_services.aspx ↩

  2. Eblex report http://www.eblex.org.uk/market-intelligence-news/uk-sheep-numbers-regional-breakdown/ ↩

  3. Meat and Livestock Australia http://www.mla.com.au/Cattle-sheep-and-goat-industries/Industry-overview/Sheep ↩

  4. I just used wikipedia’s 2012 population estimates for the two countries. ↩

  5. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breadbasket#New_Zealand ↩

  6. Ministry for Primary Industries report http://www.mpi.govt.nz/portals/0/documents/forestry/statistics/forestry-stats/facts-figures-11-12.pdf ↩

  7. Edward Tufte gives the pie chart a more succinct and decisive treatment in “The Visual Display of Quantitative Information” https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=2991062 ↩

  8. Not from the most reliable source… hccmpw.org.uk/index.php/tools/required/files/download?fID=2086 ↩

  9. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protected_areas_of_New_Zealand ↩

  10. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_parks_of_England_and_Wales ↩

  11. Mythbusters site http://www.stats.govt.nz/browse_for_stats/population/mythbusters.aspx ↩

entry.title: Simpson's paradox in diabetes (via javascript)
entry.summary: Using the D3 javascript library to visualise Simpson's paradox.
entry.content:
For the month of July (2014) I’ll be teaching medical science for a summer school in my college. Over the last week I’ve started to put together the slides I’ll be using. To help explain the concept of Simpson’s paradox I played around with rejigging somebody else’s code to fit the context of diabetes (my research area). The code used to make the plots below was originally written by the Vudlab at UC Berkeley.

I’ll let wikipedia give an introduction to the Simpson’s paradox,

Simpson’s paradox, or the Yule–Simpson effect, is a paradox in which a trend that appears in different groups of data disappears when these groups are combined, and the reverse trend appears for the aggregate data.

David Spiegelhalter, an academic who’s work I admire, contributed ideas to a paper on Simpson’s paradox that was published in the BMJ.1 One of the examples used in the paper was from the Poole diabetes cohort. The researchers broke a group of people with diabetes into two groups. One required insulin (usually type 1 diabetes), the other sub-group didn’t (type 2 diabetes).

They followed the two groups, and found that those with insulin dependent diabetes were 31% less likely (95%CI 46% to 13%) to have died during the follow up. Yet when the adjusted for age, the association flipped and those with insulin dependent diabetes were 15% more likely to have died (statistically non-significant, 95%CI -9% to 46%).

Below, each dot represents an individual from the study. Red have insulin dependent diabetes. Blue have non-insulin dependent diabetes.

In the next plot is just the people with insulin dependent diabetes. In this group 29% of people died (those that died are the red dots).

And in the next plot is the people with non-insulin dependent diabetes. In this group 40% died during follow up. So it looks like people are more likely to die with non-insulin dependent diabetes! This really doesn’t make sense, as insulin dependent diabetes is usually assumed to be a more serious manifestation of the disease (insulin is a last resort in type 2 diabetes).

The last plot below shows how the variable age helps explain what is happening. Hitting the green button will make the individuals move between groups.

This paradox occurs because people are more more likely to get type 2 diabetes later in life. People are also more likely to die later in in life. So not accounting for the age difference in the people with the two conditions means you can come to the wrong conclusions.

I’m planning on including these plots in my slides (the joy of HTML5 slides is being able to to bring in amazing plot libraries like D3).

  1. BMJ 1994;309:1480 ↩

Simpson's paradox in diabetes (via javascript) was originally published by James Black at James Black on April 29, 2014.

entry.title: The barons of bitcoin
entry.summary: Looking closely at the hacked Mt.Gox exchange, to see if there are distinct types of traders.
entry.content:
Mt. Gox was a bitcoin exchange. In 2013 it was handling about 70% of all bitcoins traded globally. Mt. Gox is actually a truncation of Magic: The Gathering Online Exchange, as Mt. Gox was originally set up to help people that wear Trillby’s trade playing cards. From late 2013 users began to complain that trades weren’t going through, or were delayed. By February 2014 Mt. Gox suspended all trading, and collapsed into bankruptcy. I’m a little hazy on what actually happened, so below is wikipedia’s take:

Mt. Gox announced that around 850,000 bitcoins belonging to customers and the company were missing and likely stolen, an amount valued at more than $450 million at the time. Although 200,000 bitcoins have since been “found”, the reason(s) for the disappearance—theft, fraud, mismanagement, or a combination of these—are unclear as of March 2014. There has been some speculation of internet hackers being responsible for the missing Bitcoins, but no speculation of such matter has been proven.

In Late 2013 hackers managed to download information on every bitcoin-to-real-money trade that occured between 2011 and 2013. They then released the dataset as a torrent, which is where I got it from. As a word of caution, all the torrents out there seem to also have viruses, so I’d avoid the dataset if you’re on windows.

Stamen, a cartography company, did a cool post where they plotted the trades of the 500 most prolific traders using this leaked data. They concluded that there where four types of traders, and picked out four users that represented those types.

Taking a gander at 500 individual plots, seemed like a pretty poor way to derive these latent groups. As I’m going to be doing some latent class trajectory modelling in an upcoming paper, and I need practice working with bigger datasets, I thought I’d have have a go seeing if these groups still exist if you let the data talk.

So what’s in the hacked dataset? (€ and $ trades have been changed to £ at a single, March 2014, rate).

  • every transaction between 1st of April 2011 and 30th November 2013,
  • which includes 8,143,064 transactions
  • between 127,065 individual user accounts
  • with a total of £1,554,995,828 exchanged1

Just to see that in rough, monthly terms,

  • In April 2011, the first month with data, there were
    • 18,341 transactions
    • between 1,112 individuals
    • with a total of £634,611 exchanged
  • While in November 2013, the last month with data, there were
    • 741,093 transactions
    • between 34,115 individuals
    • with a total of £461,373,689 exchanged (30% of the total trades happened in the last month!)

Looking through the data, I should point out there was one very strange trader, who had a bunch of trades which were blank (no bitcoins were actually transferred) - more details are in the footnotes.2

So bitcoin had a pretty meteoric rise. The gif below shows the total number of trades (x axis), against the value of the bitcoin (y axis), for each month I have data on. You can see the number of trades each month rises till late 2011, which corresponds with the first time a hacker managed to steal bitcoins from Mt. Gox.

The next plot shows the huge increase in value of a bitcoin over time. From April till June, in 2011, the price went from less than a pound, to over £100. After this first bubble burst, it wasn’t till 2013 till the price recovered - before it promptly went all the way up to more than £1000 pounds. So a £1 investment in 2011 would net you a £1000 pounds per coin gain in 2013 - hindsight is just a bit cruel sometimes.

So, as time went by, and the value of a bitcoin rose, did the amount of money changing hands in each trade also go up? The following gif plots the median value of each trade against, against the median value of a bitcoin, at month intervals.

So getting back to the Stamen’s idea of their being four types of traders amongst the top 500 on Mt. Gox. Looking at 500 separate plots and subjectively making four groups is a little dubious. Group Based Trajectory Models take the subjective out of grouping trajectories, and let the data itself drive the groupings. So I decided to use such a model to see if there are prominent groups of traders amongst the 127,065 traders I had data on.

Now this all needs to be taken with a grain of salt. This model is full of outliers, and I’m using pretty contrived proxies as the dependent and independent variables. I didn’t follow the usual process of using BIC and AIC to decide on the number of groups. Instead, I just modelled 4-8 groups, and took the ones that looked interesting (The BIC suggests I should of made more than six groups). Even with the 16GB of RAM on my laptop, each model took around 2 hours to converge, which is why I didn’t spend time fine tuning the model.

So the following results are not intended to be a robust analysis - I’m doing this to get to learn the R packages. I happen to be using the bitcoin dataset just because it’s interesting

So, in the next plot, I’m looking at total monthly balance of their account. I.e, if they brought £10 of coins, and sold £12, that net £2 is what I’m interested in. I did it this way as I want to see who was holding on to their coins over time. Going in I thought there would be three groups,

  1. Miners, accounts that mainly sell mined bitcoins
  2. Dabblers, people that don’t really trade, or just buy coins for specific purchases, and keep their monthly balance around zero.
  3. Gamblers, people that have brought up coins and sat on them

The model though identified that there were at least six latent trajectories in the data.

So how many people are in each group?

  • 18% in Traj_1,
    • hoarders, who brought in early and again as the price rose in early 2013
  • 5% in Traj_2,
    • silk roaders? This is the group that hung around a monthly balance of zero. They either don’t trade much, or were balancing out their trades, presumably buying and spending bitcoins evenly.
  • 1% in Traj_3,
    • miners, brought in a little at the start, but then consistently only sold bitcoins
  • 52% in Traj_4,
    • chumps, brought in heavily, particularly right up to the exchange collapsing
  • 3% in Traj_5,
    • the traders, brought when the price was low (2012) sold when it was high (2013). A proportion invested massively in bitcoin just before the dataset ends, which skews this group in the last month.
  • 20% in Traj_6,
    • like the silk roaders, but they had began to amass some coins before the exchange closed

Which means, there is still more than 1700 people represented by trajectory 3, the smallest group representing 1%! In the plot above, the top 500 of the Stamen post will be completely drowned out by the 100,000+ traders that, as you can see, tend to trade relatively small amounts. I should stress, this six group model does not fit well. Each individual is assigned a probability of being within each of the six trajectories. A mean probability of >0.7 for each group is considered the absolute minimum for a model that explains the data well. This model averages around 0.65.

So what happens if I look just within the top 500, like Stamen did in their post?

Like Stamen, I also subsetted the data so it was just the 500 people that traded the most by volume. As the underlying distributions in the whole sample weren’t ideal, for the top 500 I’ve used a mediod based clustering approach. So rather than finding trajectories that are similar and grouping them, this time I can’t taken the following three characteristics, and grouped people based on who is similar to who,

  1. total balance, which gives an indication if they stockpiled bitcoins, sold (maybe mined?) bitcoins, or brought as much as they sold
  2. total number of trades over the years I have data
  3. the median price they paid for a bitcoin, to try and get an indication on wether they brought in when it was cheap, or didn’t start till it was expensive

The data suggested there are six groups. Below are violin plots showing the distribution of the three characteristics used to make the groups, by the groups that were derived. The numbers in each grouped were as follows:

  • G1, 69 people
  • G2, 392 people
  • G3, 121 people
  • G4, 7 people
  • G5, 185 people
  • G6, 201 people
  • G7, 420 people
  • G8, 415 people
  • G9, 459 people

Looking at the these plots, possible the group “G9” were the unfortunate souls that Stamen suggests brought into bitcoin late. Although, as I’ve seen the model fit, I would probably conclude that the methods we use to cluster people and trajectories in medical research don’t cope very well with the chaotic distributions present in financial data, and these models don’t really tell us much.

It looks like in this case, Stamen eyeballing some graphs and coming up with groups is probably outperforming both my group based trajectory model, and my mediod based take on k-means clustering.

  1. It’s important to note that this those not mean £1.5 billion pounds was ever in the exchange. For example, a silk road user may buy bitcoin to buy something, then a day later the seller may recirculate the same bitcoins to get the payment out as cash. ↩

  2. One trader stands out as rather strange. TIBANNE_LIMITED_HK, a pretty prolific trader. In 272,007 trades they traded with themselves, although zero coins actually changed hands. I don’t fully understand what’s going on, but I think they are big brokerage for bitcoins, and so these might be automated transfers. I recommend googling “Mt.Gox TIBANNE_LIMITED_HK” if you’re interested. A surprising number of individuals link this trader to numerous new world order conspiracies, which is also why I didn’t find a site I felt comfortable linking to myself. ↩

The barons of bitcoin was originally published by James Black at James Black on April 18, 2014.

entry.title: Publish or perish - there's a model for that.
entry.summary: Scraping Google Scholar for publications and predicting an h index.
entry.content:
A rather contentious talking point in academia is the belief that it’s publish or perish. Fanning the flames of this debate are measures like the H-index1, which attempt to distill a researchers impact on the body of knowledge into a single metric.

Top explain the H-index, I’ll rely on the quote below, which was written by Daniel Acuna.

One popular measure of success is physicist Jorge Hirsch’s h-index, which captures the quality (citations) and quantity (number) of papers, thus representing scientific achievements better than either factor alone. A scientist has an h-index of n if he or she has published n articles receiving at least n citations each. Einstein, Darwin and Feynman, for example, have impressive h-indices of 96, 63 and 53, respectively. According to Hirsch, an h-index of 12 for a physicist — meaning 12 papers with at least 12 citations each — could qualify him or her for tenure at a major university.

Acuna and his co-authors developed a model to predict future H-index2, based on previous publications and citations. Their sample contained 3,085 neuroscientists, 57 Drosophila researchers and 151 evolutionary scientists. From this population they built, and published, a model that explains about the same amount of variation in the outcome as the cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk score that is recommended for use in UK practices.

Unlike a CVD risk score though, there has been no external validations, so we don’t know how well this model performs outside of the 3,000ish neuroscientists…

So with a plethora of caveats in hand - like always - there is an R package to connect this model to people’s Google Scholar profiles.

I should stress now that I consider this model, and the H-index in general, a fun metric to play with. And not a true measure of the relevance and impact of someones research

So first the packages needed to run this analysis. 

library(devtools) # get the latest version
install_github("jkeirstead/scholar") # google scholar package
library(xkcd) # xkcd graphs!
library(extrafont) # xkcd fonts
library(ggplot2) # best package ever

And check the connection with google scholar. For the id, it’s the bit after user= in your google scholar profile url.

id_j <- '-S7V41QAAAAJ'
james <- get_profile(id_j)
attach(james)
  name # me!
  total_cites # 1129 (although only as I'm one of 300 people
              # on the WHO Global Burden of Disease paper
  h_index # 5
  i10_index # 3
detach(james)

And now I’ll scrape one of my two supervisors pages.

id_s <- '6WC1bewAAAAJ'
simon <- get_profile(id_s)
attach(simon)
  name # Simon Griffin MBBS MSc DM FRCGP
  total_cites # 9673
  h_index # 50
  i10_index # 118
detach(simon)

The google scholar package allows you to compare the citations for different authors over time. In the following code block I pull the citations per year for myself, one of my supervisors, and the Winston Professor for the Public Understanding of Risk (an academic at Cambridge with one of my dream jobs).

ids <- c('oz7MFu0AAAAJ', id_s,id_j)

# Compare their career trajectories, based on year of first citation
df <- compare_scholar_careers(ids)

xrange <- range(df$career_year)
yrange <- range(df$cites)

png("hindex_plot1.png",width=800)
ggplot(df, aes(x=career_year, y=cites)) + 
  geom_line(aes(linetype=name,colour=name))+
  xkcdaxis(xrange,yrange)+
  ylab("Citations that year") + 
  xlab("Year since first citation") + 
  ggtitle(expression(atop("Comparing citations", 
                          atop(italic("Cam's Prof of Risk, my supervisor and me"), ""))))+
  theme(legend.position=c(0.3, 0.85))
dev.off()

So my career is quite a bit behind - but as I’m only in the 2nd year of my PhD, I’m also not really an academic yet.

Now to the H-index. The following code will use the google scholar profiles of myself and the two other people who’s data I pulled to calculate the predicted trajectories of our H-indexes over the next 10-years. As I mentioned before - this model has not been validated in epidemiologists, so this is just for interest.

## Predict my h-index
simon_h <- predict_h_index(id_s) 
  simon_h$name <- "Prof Griffin"
james_h <- predict_h_index(id_j)
  james_h$name <- "James Black"
david_h <- predict_h_index("oz7MFu0AAAAJ")
  david_h$name <- "Prof Spiegelhalter"

h_index <- rbind(simon_h,james_h)
h_index <- rbind(h_index,david_h)

Now I have a dataframe with predicted H-indexes, so I can plot them. Using an XKCD theme of course.

xrange <- range(h_index$years_ahead)
yrange <- range(h_index$h_index)

png("hindex_plot2.png",width=800)
ggplot(h_index, aes(x=years_ahead, y=h_index)) + 
  geom_line(aes(linetype=name,colour=name))+
  xkcdaxis(xrange,yrange)+
  ylab("Predicted H index") + 
  xlab("Years from 2014") + 
  ggtitle(expression(atop("Predicting H index over the next 10 years", 
                          atop(italic("For Cam's Prof of Risk, my supervisor and me"), ""))))+
  theme(legend.position=c(0.60, 0.40))
dev.off()

So according to this model my H-index should increase from it’s current level of 5, to 16 in 10-years time. 10-years from now it will be 8.5 years since I submitted my PhD. So I would be incredibly stoked to have 16 papers with more than 16 citations for each. Better yet, it suggests my current trajectory seems to avoid perish. Sadly, I don’t have much faith in the prophetic abilities of this model, especially as it’s based off only a handful of publications.

I’m also really hoping no-one at a funding body or fellowship board gets carried away with this model. I’m afraid that the big winners from these sorts of scores becoming more important would be the vanity publishers like Hindawi and Dove Press, who will publish anything for a fee.

  1. Hirsch. Proc. Natl Acad. Sci. USA 102, 16569–16572 (2005) ↩

  2. Acuna. Nature 489, 201–202 (2012) ↩

Publish or perish - there's a model for that. was originally published by James Black at James Black on April 11, 2014.
